Why are American washing machines not popular in Europe? American washing machines have a hot and cold hose with imperial threads. Replacement hoses are £33 each, or £66 every five years. European washing machines have a heating element and only need one cold hose. European hoses are £5. You could buy an adapter to fit the European hose to the American machine, but they cost £30 each. Also super important to know, is that by using too much laundry detergent (especially in front load washers) you risk the soap eating away at the grease around the bearing that holds the inner tub in place, which causes the bearing to rust and seize. Effectively wrecking your machine. it is definitely not as much of an issue with older, top load style washing machines, but with our modern washing machines, it can actually be a huge problem. Tack on the fact that most people actually are using way too much soap for their machines... in fact, when you have a load of laundry running, you should not be able to look inside the wash tub and see any additional suds. suds are a sign of using too much detergent in your wash, and can lead to signifigant failure of your machine.

Using too much HE detergent in an HE washer will cause your washer to break down very quickly as they rely on filters to recycle water for the rinse cycle. This is how they are high efficient. I sell appliances, this is the one thing I always tell people when they transition from an older washer to an HE washer.

If you use too much (not excessive like this video, but using the measuring cup) detergent consistently, over time it will remove the lubricant around the drum and actually damage the machine.  My parents had to get major work done on their washer because we followed the bottle of detergent directions for how much to use.  The repairman said to use only 1 tablespoon per load in that high efficiency machine.

Folks - really loved that episode! I’ve worked for a soap company for many years, and the products you used are very familiar to me. Couple of tips:
1) I noticed you’ve used HE (high efficiency) detergent for the video (presumably, this is what the instructions for the washer said). HE detergent has much lower levels of suds (# of bubbles/volume) than non-HE. Also, powder detergent tends to have higher suds than liquids. And finally, suds need proper water temperatures to activate. If you re-run the experiment with non-HE powder detergent (and hot water), you’ll have that machine bursting with bubbles. Should make for some great visuals.
2) most front-loader washing machines have heating elements, most top loaders do not. If you cannot hook it up to a hot water supply, get a front-loader.
3) the “waxy” feeling you get from over-dosing with fabric softener are the remnants of the surfactants built into the softener formula. The surfactants essentially coat the fibers of the fabrics and this is what makes these fabrics feel “soft”. It also makes them less absorbent. There are various ways to get rid of these surfactants (heat, oxygen, acid, acrid smoke).
